My main interests are in developing databases and software for bioinformatics,
especially in the analysis of microarray data from Mycosphaerella graminicola chips with
I am also involved in the annotation of the Fusarium graminearum genome
Martin Urban, and Richard Coulson at the EBI.
I am developing plant virus genome web databases and PC client software with
and the light leafspot forecast web software with
I am also interested in developing molecular biology software
(e.g. BioLab in The Molecular Biology Notebook with Nathalie Castells-Brooke)
for use in education at A-level in schools
Here is a list of some my software:
• RESearch - DNA sequence analysis especially restriction enzyme sites
• GeneMap - a web browser helper application for displaying sequences
• Descriptions of Plant Viruses on CD-ROM - plant virus database and software
• Molecular Biology Notebook - educational molecular biology course
• PCR primer design - primer database, and analysis and design software
• SNP Enzyme Finder - finds restriction enzymes which can detect SNPs
This site provides a comprehensive resource for plant virology including:
• An on-line version of most of the DPV software and databases with virus descriptions, taxonomic and sequence information.

• a virus sequence database and software that we are developing for the analysis of virus genomes. Modules currently available are for Codon Use analysis, Transmembrane protein prediction and for downloading selected nucleotide or amino acid sequences in FASTA format.
• Details of our stand-alone DPV CD-ROM marketed by AAB.
• A classified list of all plant virus and viroid sequences from the EMBL and Genbank databases classified by virus or viroid name. A separate list of viruses of fungi and protozoa is also provided.
A selection of electron micrographs produced by plant pathologists at Rothamsted.
Prediction of the severity of light leafspot disease on Winter oilseed rape.
A comprehensive package for the hands-on teaching of Molecular Biology.
TMCompare: transmembrane region sequence and structure.
Plant virus transmission by plasmodiophorid fungi is associated with
distinctive transmembrane regions of virus-encoded proteins.
